A Big Weekend for Brooks County Cats: 19 Spayed and Neutered

It was a big weekend for the cats of Brooks County. Five stray cats from a single Quitman homeowner were spayed or neutered this weekend, bringing the total at that location to 15 cats over the past few months ‚Äî with another 14 cats from surrounding areas also receiving surgery.

It was a big weekend for the cats of Brooks County. Five stray cats from Quitman were spayed or neutered this past weekend, and an additional 14 cats from surrounding areas also received the same life-changing surgery ‚Äî 19 cats total who will never contribute to the cycle of overpopulation again.

15 Cats and Counting in Quitman

This weekend's five cats mark a milestone. Over the past few months, Sam's TNR has now assisted a single Quitman homeowner in spaying or neutering 15 cats. What started as a few strays showing up at the door grew into a colony ‚Äî and without intervention, those 15 cats could have produced hundreds of kittens in just a few years.

That's the math that makes TNR so critical. One unspayed female can produce up to three litters per year, with four to six kittens each. Multiply that across 15 unaltered cats, and the numbers escalate fast. Thanks to persistent effort and a willing homeowner, this colony is now stabilized.

Weekend by the Numbers

5

Quitman cats fixed this weekend

14

Cats from surrounding areas

15

Total cats fixed at this Quitman location

It Takes a Team

Weekends like this don't happen without collaboration. A special thank you to All Saints Cat TNR, who both coordinated and sponsored this project, and Paws First Mobile Veterinary Clinic, whose team performed the surgeries. These partnerships are what make large-scale TNR efforts possible in rural communities like ours.

The Work Isn't Done

Quitman and Brooks County still have many cats in need. Stray and feral populations don't stabilize overnight ‚Äî it takes sustained, community-wide effort. Every cat we spay or neuter is one less source of new litters, but there are always more cats waiting.

If you know of stray or feral cats in the Quitman or Brooks County area, reach out to Sam's TNR. We can assess the situation and work with you to get those cats fixed.

Help Us Keep Going

Every surgery costs money ‚Äî veterinary fees, traps, transportation, and recovery supplies add up. Your donation directly funds the next cat's surgery.

Sam's TNR is a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit. All donations are tax-deductible.
